Under Indian parliamentary democracy, is it possible to ensure balanced regional development? Please elaborate with reasons and examples.

According to Indian parliamentary regulation acts the members in the house has to ensure all the regions in the country has equal development. For example in the bifurcation of two states Telangana and Andhra both has to get the equal  rights and development in each particular aspects like employment, infrastructure, water etc. the head of the parliament should have an eye on all  those aspects.

states like Gujarat, Dehli, Mubai etc.. are developed states and contributing for the development of the country, the members  has to focus on the states like Behar, Madhya pradesh, which are still under developing states. the members of parliamentary (MP) has to study the issues in the sates and  for-cast the required solutions, budget for the development.

yes, it is possible to ensure balanced regional development in the country by electing a persons who has spirit in the belli to work for the country and for the development. on the other hand the opposition parties in the parliament should bring the issues and explain the problems facing by people in the country. which has to discussed and solve by passing the acts with majority stake like food bill, janlokpall bill, telangana bill etc..  

state like Gujarat has developed rapidly from the past 5 years in all the  sectors. the regional imbalances will appear only when the elected members does not focus on the issues happening in the economy. the corporate companies, small scale industries, global companies focus on those states which are developed, government has to encourage the investors to start their business in the underdeveloped states which results in employment opportunities and development of infrastructure like road ways, railways etc..
